contextId.information: This is a command  to stare at the model of the city as a symbol of punishing the city. AT: "stare at the city" or "stare at the city so that it will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against it

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at the model of Jerusalem as a symbol of punishing Jerusalem. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:3]]. AT: "Stare at Jerusalem" or "Stare at Jerusalem so that it will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: Set your face toward Jerusalem

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at the mountains as a symbol of punishing the people there.  See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:3]]. AT: "stare at the mountains of Israel" or "stare at the mountains of Israel so that the people there will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against the mountains of Israel

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at the women as a symbol of punishing them. Translate "set your face against" as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:3]]. AT: "Stare at the daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against the daughters

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of being opposed to them as if he were to set his face against them. AT: "I will be against them" or "I will oppose them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I will set my face against them

contextId.information: This refers to taking hold of another person's hand as a sign of friendship and agreement. Here it represents the covenant oath that he made with the king of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: reached out with his hand to make a promise

contextId.information: The idiom "lifts up his eyes" refers to looking toward something. With reference to idols, this gesture represents worshiping or praying to idols. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:18:05|18:6]]. AT: "he worships the idols" or "he prays to the idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: he lifts up his eyes to the idols

contextId.information: Here "raised my hand" is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:20:04|20:5]]. AT: "I myself also solemnly swore an oath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I myself also raised my hand to swear an oath

contextId.information: Here "lifted up my hand" is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. AT: "I myself also solemnly swore" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I myself also lifted up my hand to swear

contextId.information: Here "lifted up my hand" is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. AT: "I have solemnly sworn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I have lifted up my hand to swear

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at the southern lands as a symbol of punishing the people there. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:3]]. AT: "Stare at the southern lands" or "Stare at the southern lands so that they will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face toward the southern lands

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at Jerusalem as a symbol of punishing the people there. AT: "stare at Jerusalem" or "stare at Jerusalem so that the people there will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face toward Jerusalem

contextId.information: Jerusalem was far away, so Ezekiel could not see it, but staring in that direction would be a symbol of harming it. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:01|6:2]] AT: "Turn toward Jerusalem and stare" or "stare toward Jerusalem so that the people there will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face toward Jerusalem

contextId.information: "I have shaken my fist against" or "I have clapped my hands against." This is a symbolic action that shows anger and disapproval. AT: "I have shown my anger and disapproval against" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: With my hand I have struck

contextId.information: In Israel, men would shave their beards to express sorrow, then cover their faces until their facial hair grew back. Yahweh told Ezekiel to not cover his facial hair to show that he had not shaved his face to express his sorrow. AT: "do not mourn by veiling your facial hair" or "do not mourn by shaving and covering your beard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: do not veil your facial hair

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at the people of Ammon as a symbol of punishing them. AT: "stare at the people of Ammon" or "stare at the people of Ammon so that they will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against the people of Ammon

contextId.information: Ammon was far away, so Ezekiel could not see the people there, but staring in that direction would be a symbol of harming the people. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:01|6:2]]. AT: "Turn toward the people of Ammon and stare" or "stare toward Ammon so that the people there will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against the people of Ammon

contextId.information: These actions are ways to show strong emotions. In this case they people are cheering and showing their contempt against Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: You have clapped your hands and stamped your feet

contextId.information: These are expressions of grieving and mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: They will shave their heads bald for you and bind themselves with sackcloth

contextId.information: This is a command to stare at Pharaoh as a symbol of punishing him and his people. AT: "stare at Pharaoh" or "stare at Pharaoh so that he and his people will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against Pharaoh

contextId.information: Pharaoh was far away, so Ezekiel could not see  him, but staring in his direction would be a symbol of harming him and his people. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:01|6:2]]. AT: "turn toward Pharaoh and stare" or "stare toward Pharaoh so that he and his people will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against Pharaoh

contextId.information: Mount Seir was far away, so Ezekiel could not see it, but Yahweh commands him to stare in that direction as a symbol of harming the people there. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:01|6:2]]. AT: "turn toward Mount Seir and stare" or "stare toward Mount Seir so that the people there will be harmed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: set your face against Mount Seir

contextId.information: Here "lift up my hand" is a symbolic action that shows he will truly do what he has sworn to do. AT: "I solemnly swear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: I myself will lift up my hand to swear
